metadata.title: Eating Disorders  Occupational Therapy
synonyms: eating disorder not otherwise specified (occupational therapy)
anatomical location body part affected: All systems of the body are affected by eating disorders, including the cardiovascular, dermatologic, oropharyngeal, endocrine, metabolic, gastrointestinal, nervous, and reproductive systems; eating disorders also affect mental health
description: An eating disorder is a condition that involves extreme emotions, attitudes, and behaviors regarding weight and food issues.(1) A person with an eating disorder experiences serious emotional and physical problems that can have life-threatening consequences.(1) The term eating disorders encompasses anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), binge eating disorder (BED; also called compulsive overeating), and eating disorder not otherwise specified (EDNOS)(1)

AN is a psychological eating disorder characterized by low body weight due to self-imposed  severe dietary restriction or other weight loss behaviors (e.g., excessive physical activity) motivate by an intense fear of weight gain and a distorted body image(1)

BN is an eating disorder in which a person engages in a cycle of binge eating and subsequent purging. Individuals with BN often eat large amounts of food (more than most persons would consume in one meal) within a short period of time, and then eliminate the food and calories through vomiting, laxative abuse, or overexercising(1,3)

BED is an eating disorder in which a person engages in uncontrolled, impulsive, or continuous eating beyond the point of feeling comfortably full; there is no purging; however, the person may take part in sporadic fasts or repeatedly diet(1)

EDNOS: Other eating disorders can include a combination of the signs and symptoms of AN, BN, and/or BED.(4,5) While individuals with these disorders do not necessarily meet the criteria for another diagnosable eating disorder, these patterns of disordered eating can still result in significant physical and emotional problems(1,4,5)

Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition  (DSM-5 ) diagnostic criteria: –AN -Restriction of energy intake relative to caloric requirements that leads to a significantly low body weight (i.e., less than minimally normal or minimally expected) given the person’s age, sex, physical health, and developmental trajectory(31) -Intense fear of gaining weight or being fat despite a low body weight(31)  -Inability to recognize the seriousness of one’s low body weight or evaluate one’s own body weight or shape(31) -Subtypes: restricting type, binge-eating/purging type(31) -Severity(31) -Mild: BMI ≥ 17 kg/m2 -Moderate: BMI 16–16.99  kg/m2 -Severe: BMI 15–15.99  kg/m2 -Extreme: BMI < 15 kg/m2 –BN -Recurrent episodes of binge eating(31) -Recurrent episodes of inappropriate behaviors intended to prevent weight gain (e.g., self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives)(31) -Binge eating and compensatory behaviors occur, on average, at least once every 3 weeks(31) -Evaluation of self is highly influenced by body shape/weight(31) -Episodes do not exclusively occur within episodes of AN(31) -Severity -Mild: Average of 1–3 inappropriate compensatory behaviors per week(31) -Moderate: Average of 4–7 inappropriate compensatory behaviors per week(31) -Severe: Average of 8–13  inappropriate compensatory behaviors per week(31) -Extreme: Average of 14+ inappropriate compensatory behaviors per week(31) –BED -Recurrent episodes of binge eating associated with at least three of the following characteristics: -Eating much more rapidly than normal(31) -Eating until uncomfortably full(31) -Eating large amounts of food despite not feeling physically hungry(31) -Eating alone because one is embarrassed by how much is being eaten(31) -Feelings of disgust, depression, or guilt after eating(31) -Considerable distress is associated with binge eating(31) -A disorder is diagnosed if binge eating occurs on averageonce a week for 3 months(31) -Episodes are not associated with BN or do not occur exclusively during the course of BN(31) -Severity -Mild: 1–3 sessions of binge eating per week(31) -Moderate: 4–7 sessions of binge eating per week(31) -Severe: 8–13  sessions of binge eating per week(31) -Extreme: 14+ sessions of binge eating per week(31)

Authors of a systematic review evaluated 94 studies conducted from 2000 to 2018 to determine the lifetime prevalence of eating disorders (studies were conducted in countries across North and South America, Europe, and Asia). They looked only at studies that included an accurate eating disorder diagnosis (based on DMV-5 diagnosis). They found the weight means (the weighted means were calculated from the prevalence data and the population size of each study) of lifetime eating disorders were 8.4% for women and 2.2% for men(36)

ICD-10 codes.F50.4: overeating associated with other psychological disturbances
ICD-10 codes.F50.5: vomiting associated with other psychological disturbances
ICD-10 codes.F50.9: eating disorders, unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Symptoms of AN –Inability to maintain body weight at or above a minimally normal weight for the individual’s height, body type, age, and activity level(1) -Diagnostic criteria for AN include weight loss to a body weight of 15% below expected weight given the person’s height(6) –The person is unlikely to think he or she has a problem(2) –Cold temperature intolerance(2,6) –Complicated food preparation and eating rituals(2) –Constipation and bloating(6) –Decreased bone density; fractures(2) –Dry or scaly skin(2,6) –Excessive concern with body weight and shape(1,2,6) –Extreme fear of weight gain or being fat(1,2) –Feeling fat or overweight even when emaciated(1,2) –Growth arrest; delayed puberty(2) –Increased lanugo body hair(2,6) –Intensive/excessive exercise(2) –Pallor(7) –Parotid enlargement/edema(6) –Scalp hair loss(2) –In severe cases, bradycardia, hypotension, and hypothermia can occur(6)

Symptoms of BN –Repeated cycles (usually in private) of uncontrolled bingeing and purging(1) -Diagnostic criteria for BN include episodes of binge eating at least twice weekly for 3 months(6) –Feeling out of control and eating past the point of comfortable fullness during a binge(1) –Purging after a binge(1,6) -Self-induced  vomiting(1,6) -Abuse of laxatives, diet pills, and/or diuretics(1,6) -Excessive exercise(1,6) -Fasting(1,6) –Repeated episodes of dieting(1) –Body weight frequently fluctuates but is usually within 20% of a desirable weight(3,6) –Excessive concern with body weight and shape(1,6) –Sore throat(3) –Lethargy and fatigue(3) –Erosion of tooth enamel(3)  –Asymptomatic, noninflammatory parotid gland enlargement(3) –Calluses, abrasions, bruising on the hand and/or thumb(3) –Peripheral edema(3) –Bradycardia(3) –Epigastric tenderness to palpation(3)

Symptoms of BED –Episodes of binge eating without purging(1) –Feelings of shame or self-hatred  following a binge(1) –Anxiety, depression, and loneliness(1) –Body weight can range from normal to severe obesity(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Occupational therapy evaluations for patients with eating disorders should utilize a client-centered  approach to most effectively evaluate deficits and needs(13)

A client-centered  approach includes the following principles:(14) –The patient is uniquely qualified to make decisions about their occupational functioning –The patient should have an active role in determining goals and desired outcomes –The patient-therapist  relationship should be interdependent –Evaluation and treatment should focus on the patient’s culture, roles, interests, etc. –When the patient can define the problems on which they would like to work, the patient also becomes a problem solver –The patient should evaluate their own performance and set personal goals

causes: the causes of eating disorders: It is the position of the Academy for Eating Disorders (AED) that eating disorders are biologically based mental illnesses(8)–One theory derived from the idea that eating disorders have an underlying psychiatric etiology posits that refusal to eat ina person with AN is a means to regain control of one’s body in defiance of parental control(6)

There is an indication that some persons have an underlying genetic predisposition to develop an eating disorder; however,this genetic mechanism is not well understood(2,8,9,10)–Having a first-degree  female relative with an eating disorder increases a person’s risk six- to tenfold.(2)Having afirst-degree  male relative with AN increases a female’s risk of developing AN twentyfold(10)–Additionally, twin studies have found that 50–83%  of the variance in eating disorders is accounted for by geneticfactors(8)

Multiple endocrinologic, metabolic, and neurochemical abnormalities are found in patients with AN; however, it appearsthat these abnormalities are a result of malnutrition and not a cause of the disorder(6,8)
pathogenesis: The predominant age at onset of AN is 13–20  years;(2) the mean age at onset of BN is 18–21  years(3)
Eating disorders arise from a complex relationship among biologic, psychological, environmental, and social factors thatresults in an unrealistic perception of one’s body and weight(2,9)
risk factors: Sex (females are at significantly higher risk than males)(2,3,6)
Age (those in their teens to late twenties are most at risk)(32)
Culture (more common in Western cultures; however, incidence is increasing in Asian cultures)(7)
Early adversity (e.g., family dysfunction, conflict in the home, cold/unsupportive/neglectful family relationships)(29)
History of emotional disorders (anxiety, depression, OCD)(32)
Member of a family that is highly goal-  and achievement-oriented(6)
Parental overemphasis on child weight/body shape(9,11)
Parental psychiatric disorder or substance abuse(2,3)
Participation in sports or artistic activities that emphasize leanness or involve subjective scoring (e.g., ballet, running,wrestling, figure skating, gymnastics, cheerleading, weightlifting)(2,3)
Perfectionist, obsessive, or rigid personality type(2,3)

overall contraindications precautions: Follow physician’s orders regarding the reintroduction of all food, nutrients, and calories into the diet of a patient with an eating disorder; nutritional support for severely malnourished patients must be supervised by a nutrition professional because of the risk of refeeding syndrome, in which a patient can rapidly develop fluid and electrolyte disorders, especially hypophosphatemia, along with neurologic, pulmonary, cardiac, neuromuscular, and hematologic complications, including death(7)

The incidence of suicide attempts and suicide is much higher among patients with eating disorders than among the general population; suicide risk is slightly greater for patients with BN versus those with AN.(4) Take any verbalization of suicidal ideation seriously and inform the patient’s primary physician and/or psychiatrist
It is important to develop and establish a tolerant, empathetic relationship with the patient; patients with eating disorders are often ashamed of their behavior and can be resistant to treatment(12)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: A client-centered  approach includes the following principles:(14) –The patient is uniquely qualified to make decisions about their occupational functioning –The patient should have an active role in determining goals and desired outcomes –The patient-therapist  relationship should be interdependent –Evaluation and treatment should focus on the patient’s culture, roles, interests, etc. –When the patient can define the problems on which they would like to work, the patient also becomes a problem solver –The patient should evaluate their own performance and set personal goals

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was an eating disorder diagnosed in the patient? What specific eating disorder was diagnosed? -Review medical history, including date of diagnosis, presenting symptoms, psychological and/or neuropsychological tests and reports, drug regimen, and medical, behavioral, and social management of the eating disorder to date

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management of eating disorders will vary from patient to patient(2) Management of patients with eating disorders is often addressed by a multidisciplinary team that includes physicians, nurses, and psychological professionals who specialize in the treatment of eating disorders(2,6) Psychotherapy is usually part of the patient’s treatment for an eating disorder(6) Patients might require hospitalization to address the physical complications of an eating disorder(6) The initial objective of medical treatment is weight restoration(2) For chronic cases of AN, the goal might be to achieve a safe weight rather than a healthy weight(2) Patients with severe malnutrition as a result of an eating disorder must be hemodynamically stabilized and may require enteral or parenteral feeding(2,6)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? No medications are available to directly treat eating disorders(2,3) Medications prescribed for patients with eating disorders are usually intended to treat underlying psychological conditions such as depression or anxiety. Pharmacotherapy in isolation for patients with eating disorders is contraindicated; medications must be combined with psychotherapy(2,3) Medications commonly prescribed for patients with eating disorders Tricyclic antidepressants(6) SSRIs(3,6)  Lithium carbonate(6) Supplements of calcium and vitamin D (for treatment of osteopenia)(2,10) Elemental zinc (for patients with zinc deficiency)(10) Psyllium (to prevent constipation)(2,3) Ondansetron (between meals to prevent vomiting)(3)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Review any available diagnostic test results; diagnostic tests often include laboratory tests and blood work(6)

Laboratory findings in patients with eating disorders are variable (and can be normal) but often include anemia, leukopenia, electrolyte abnormalities, elevations of blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and serum creatinine, increased serum cholesterol levels, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, hypomagnesemia, hyponatremia, hypocalcemia, hypophosphatasemia, hypoglycemia, increased urine specific gravity, alkalosis, and reduced levels of luteinizing
An EKG can detect bradycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, conduction deficits, and ST segment depression due to hypokalemia in patients with eating disorders(3)
Patients often undergo a full neurological workup to rule out another cause of weight loss and/or vomiting(2)
Dual-energy  X-ray  absorptiometry (DEXA) of the bone is indicated if the patient has been underweight for longer than 6 months to determine if there is diminished bone density(2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help Bright light therapy has been shown to help some patients with BN(3) Patients with AN often complain of cold extremities and may have lower core temperatures. Authors of a study (N=41) analyzed the thermogenic effects of footbaths with medicinal powders in adolescents with AN. They assessed whether footbaths containing warm water and mustard ( Sinapis nigra ), warm water and ginger ( Zingiber officinale ), or warm water only produced subjective and/or objective changes in warmth in patients with AN when compared to healthy controls(37) Footbaths with warm water and ginger increased perceived warmth of the patients’ feet longer than the footbaths with warm water and mustard or warm water only in both patients with AN and healthy controls
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Determine if there are factors (such as parental comments on weight, participation in sports or dance events that emphasize thinness, etc.) that trigger negative self-talk  or episodes of bingeing, purging, or self-starvation(3)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician -Complications associated with eating disorders include stunted growth, heart disease, depression, suicidal thoughts or behaviors, bone loss, seizures, severe tooth decay, and kidney damage(32) -There is an increased risk of fractures in patients with osteopenia/osteoporosis as a result of an eating disorder(4) -Repeated episodes of vomiting can lead to Mallory-Weiss  tears (a tear of the mucous membrane of the lower part of the esophagus or upper part of the stomach) in patients with BN(3) -In females, fertility can be affected by eating disorders(2,7)  -For pregnant women with eating disorders, there is an increased risk of preterm delivery, operative delivery, and giving birth to an infant with low birth weight, small head circumference, and/or microcephaly(2,3)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document respiratory status; patients with severe malnutrition can have difficulty breathing(2,7) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a history of an eating disorder? Has the patient relapsed from prior treatment for an eating disorder?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Co-occurring  diagnoses commonly associated with eating disorders include mental health problems such as depressive, anxiety, impulsecontrol,  and substance use disorders as well as social phobia and cluster C personality disorders(2,3,4,6) AN often coexists with chronic medical disorders such as diabetes and cystic fibrosis(2) Studies have found an increased incidence of ADHD among patients with eating disorders as compared to the general population(4)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs) Patients with eating disorders sometimes abuse diet pills, diuretics, laxatives, and other medications(2,3)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What are the patient’s occupations/role(s) within their family, school, peer group, etc.?(12,15) -What activities, hobbies, etc., does the patient enjoy?(12,15) -Patients with eating disorders sometimes lose interest in activities they once found pleasurable(12) -The patient’s previously productive occupations can become replaced by the highly structured routines that are developed to support self-starvation,  bingeing, and purging(12) -It is important to determine what activities are/were important to the patient to motivate them to participate in therapy(15) -Additionally, it is important to gauge the level of participation in activities, such as exercise, to determine if the patient is participating to excess(12) -A patient/caregiver interview may be helpful to gain insight into the patient’s hobbies, family/community roles, interests, current or prior work status, and home responsibilities
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What current assistive or adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home? Can it still be utilized based on patient’s current level of functioning? -Document both high-  and low-tech  adaptations and equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? -Does the patient have supportive family members? Do those family members live near and/or have the ability to provide assistance? -Parents of adolescents with eating disorders must be involved in the therapeutic process, as the emphasis on body image and thinness often originates with the parents(11)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Note BMI; BMI and body weight in patients with eating disorders can range from significantly underweight to obese(1)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or current use of assistive and adaptive devices; patients with eating disorders are at increased risk for fractures from malnutrition-related  osteopenia and may require assistive devices for mobility or ADLs –Mobility aids -Cane -Walker -Wheelchair -Crutches -Hemi-walker -Ankle-foot  orthoses (AFOs) –Toileting and showering equipment -Grab bars -Bedside commode -Urinal at bedside -Raised toilet seat -Shower chair/tub bench -Elevated footrest at the toilet –ADL/IADL aids -Reachers -Personal digital assistant (PDA) -Large-print  reading material -Adaptive/ergonomic computer/mouse/keyboard -Adaptive cooking equipment
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance functionally during ADLs –Tinetti Balance Scale(17) –Berg Balance Scale –Functional Reach Test
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate regularly pre/during/post activity; use Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale if indicated -Patients with AN often have cardiac arrhythmia, orthostatic hypotension, and/or decreased pulse and/or respiratory rate(2,7)
Monitor breathing to assist with determining fatigue and endurance levels
Assess functional exercise capacity as appropriate (e.g., obese patients with binge eating disorder): 6-minute  walk test(34)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalities –Patients with eating disorders can present with bradycardia(3,6)Bed mobility and transfers should be assessed to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity –Test static and dynamic activitiesa measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seating position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, all of which are important for independent mobility(18)  –FIM – an 18-item,  7-level  ordinal scale assessing functional mobility, ADLs, language skills, and cognition(19)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted) –Note use of braces or ambulatory aids for walking –If the patient presents with impaired gait, referral to physical therapy may be appropriateAssess fine and gross motor function of the upper extremities; describe the quality of movement
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength –Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers; do not perform MMT with contracted muscles or muscles with tone and coordination issues –Dynamometer to evaluate hand strength bilaterally –Assess grip force in functional tasks –Assess pinch strength
observation inspection palpation includi: Ocular motor screening includes tracking through all planes, visual accommodation, and clarity of vision
Document complaints of double vision, optic pain, or visual field cuts
Referral to ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology  is appropriate if symptoms of visual disturbances are noted during
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Patients with eating disorders can have cognitive dysfunction as a result of malnutrition(12) –A brief cognitive assessment such as the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) is appropriate for patients with eating disorders(16) –For patients with significant cognitive impairment, referral to neuropsychology for extensive assessment and input regarding cognitive intervention is appropriate

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment
There is an increased risk of fractures in patients with osteopenia/osteoporosis as a result of an eating disorder(4)
Patients with AN often have cardiac arrhythmia, orthostatic hypotension, and/or decreased pulse and/or respiratory rate.(2,7) Refer to physician guidelines regarding exercise restrictions

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The occupational therapist (OT) will determine the need for intervention after a comprehensive evaluation; the OT must consider each patient’s risk factors and deficits to determine if the patient is an appropriate candidate for therapy
assessment plan of care.rule out: Prior to diagnosing an eating disorder, the medical team will rule out Anxiety disorders; food phobia(2,3) Body dysmorphic disorder(3) Borderline personality disorder(3) Cancer(6) CNS disorders(2,6) Chronic infections(2,6) Conversion disorder(2) Depressive disorders(2,3) Endocrine and metabolic disorders (e.g., panhypopituitarism, Addison disease, diabetes mellitus)(2,3,6) Gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., Crohn’s disease, celiac sprue)(2,6) Hypothalamic brain tumor(3) Hyperthyroidism/hypothyroidism(2,3) Immunodeficiency(2) Kleine-Levin  syndrome(3) Malabsorption(3)  Psychogenic vomiting(3) Schizophrenia(2)
prognosis: AN: In adults the course is often protracted or relapsing. Recovery usually occurs within 5–7 years and is reported in 76% of adults at mean of 79 months (partial remission reported in 87% at mean of 59 months).(45,46) AN is associated with increased mortality, usually due to starvation-related  medical complications (particularly heart-related  complications and severe infections)(46)

BN: The median time to recovery (no binge/purge behaviors) is 3.8 years, with 68% of patients having achieved recovery at mean 22-year follow-up  in prospective cohort study of 110 females with BN(47)
BED: Reported to persist for a mean of 8 years(48)

Even with treatment, an eating disorder can have a serious impact on the patient’s QOL –For patients with BN, greater weight fluctuations, associated impulsive behaviors, and coexistence of a personality disorder are associated with poorer overall prognosis(3)
Outcomes are better for men with AN than women with AN(2)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines If not already under the care of a mental health professional, refer the patient to a psychologist, psychiatrist, and/or counselor (preferably one with experience in the treatment of eating disorders)(2,3,7) Referral to registered dietician for education on healthy diet, appropriate caloric goals, and weight management(3,7,12) –Nutritional support for severely malnourished patients must be supervised by a nutrition professional because of the risk of refeeding syndrome, in which the patient can rapidly develop fluid and electrolyte disorders, especially hypophosphatemia, along with neurologic, pulmonary, cardiac, neuromuscular, and hematologic complications, including death(7) –Patients with AN should gain weight at a rate of 1 to 2 pounds per week(7) Referral to a counselor, chaplain, or other spiritual advisor, as meditation, yoga, and other spiritual activities have been shown to benefit patients with eating disorders(22)
treatment summary: OTs are equipped to deliver purposeful-eating-related  interventions. Assisting patients in participating in purposeful-eating-related interventions may support the development of more adaptive behaviors and engagementin previously avoided occupations –Authors of a study (N = 99) introduced practical food groups into the treatment inan eating disorder day program. The intervention involved eating-related  outings (e.g., eating in a restaurant) and meal preparation groups. Each session began with a 45-minute  discussion ofcoping mechanisms that could be used during the activities. The activity lasted 60 minutes and then was followed by a 45-minute  debriefing. The day program operated from 10 am to 4pm 4 days a week and the practical food group treatment took place once a week. The average treatment length in the program was 5 weeks(38) -Based on participant questionnaires, practical food groups were considered useful and valuable, yet challenging. Most patients reported increased confidence to try feared foods, decreased anxiety about food, and new, healthier ways of eating once they were discharged from the program -Practical food groups may be useful for patients recovering from eating disorders. However, further research is neededregarding their effect on helping to sustain patients’ recovery from eating disorders

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)(1,13,15) –CBT is a highly preferred treatment option for patients with eating disorders(42)  –An OT can be trained and qualified to use CBT to aid in the rehabilitation of patients with eating disorders(13) –In general, the underlying principle that guides CBT is that a person’s thoughts and beliefs regarding a particular situation change the way in which the person acts in that situation(24,25) –When a person expects failure or difficulty, failure or difficultly is more likely; when the person expects to succeed in a situation or activity, success is more likely(24) –CBT for eating disorders aims to help patients identify situations that trigger their depressed moods and monitor negative thoughts, with the goal of preventing recurrence(3,23) -Involve the patient in the development of appropriate goals for therapy(3) -Teach the patient to self-monitor  behaviors such as food intake, frequency of binges/purges, and triggers related to bingeing and purging, as well as thoughts and emotions -Teach the patient to self-monitor  their weight weekly(3) -Educate the patient about the ineffectiveness of purging as a means of weight control as well as its harmful side effects(3) -Establish a reasonable weight goal and appropriate eating plan(3) -Assist with gradually introducing feared foods into the patient’s diet(3) -Problem-solve  ways in which to cope with internal and external triggers that result in bingeing and purging(3) -Explore the patient’s fear that he or she will lose control(3) -Determine a plan for relapse prevention(3) -Gradually facilitate the withdrawal of laxatives or diuretics(3) –Specific treatment activities for CBT with this population include:(23) -food diaries -journaling -stress management training -assertiveness training -crafts -social skills training -relaxation training -education about and engagement in appropriate physical exercise -coping skills training for meal preparation -clothes shopping -eating a meal -money management -use of video equipment -education about eating disorders –Authors of an RCT (N = 67) aimed to determine if an unguided internet CBT therapy for perfectionism could reduce eating disorder pathology, compulsive exercise, and burnout in patients who participate in regular exercise(39) -There is a link between perfectionism and eating disorders, compulsive exercise, and burnout -Patients in the intervention group received internet CBT therapy through weekly emails for 8 weeks on overcoming perfectionism -The control group, a waitlist control, did not receive any treatment during the 8 weeks -The unguided internet CBT therapy for perfectionism resulted in decreases in perfectionism, eating disorder symptomology, and compulsive exercise in patients who engage in regular exercise –In a review of the literature on treatment for patients with co-occurring  BN and substance abuse, the authors concluded that CBT is a viable treatment option for these patients; however, modifications are required to appropriately address their specific needs (e.g., reduced motivation, difficulty with interpersonal relationships, impulsivity, reward sensitivity)(26)

Physical activity –There is evidence that physical activity is associated with decreased risk of depression, anxiety, and stress-related disorders. Physical activity may protect against mental illnesses including eating disorders and be an effective intervention(40,41)  –Physical activity has been excluded from many treatment guidelines for AN. Authors of a systematic review found that physical exercise programs may be appropriate and effective treatment for some patients with AN. They found that(40) -supervised physical exercise interventions were not associated with weight loss in patients with AN -physical exercise programs should focus on resistance/strength or flexibility -physical exercise programs did not influence anthropometry, but they may improve vital signs, muscle function and strength, and eating disorder symptomatology -exercise interventions should only be performed when they are safe for patients with AN -physical exercise programs should be supervised.They are most appropriate during the late phases of rehabilitation or stabilization of patients with AN -further research is needed to determine the frequency, type, and intensity of exercise that is most beneficial for patients with AN –Authors of an RCT compared the effects of a physical exercise and dietary therapy (PED-t)  treatment to CBT in patients with either BN or BED. Both groups received 20 therapy sessions(42) -PED-t  group (N = 76):Patients received combined progressive resistance exercise training and high-intensity  interval running (45 minutes per session) with dietary therapy (60 minutes per session). Patients attended education sessions and participated in group discussion on behavioral and practical skills -CBT group (N = 73):Patients met1–2  times per weekfor 90-minute  sessions in which theydiscussed the four main stages of CBT for eating disorders:engagement and behavioral change, monitoring and evaluating progress, addressing the core ED pathology, and relapse prevention -Both treatment groups had significant improvements in symptoms of BN and BED, subjective well-being,  and psychosocial impairment. The PED-t  group had reduced symptoms of depression -PED-t  is equally effective as CBT for treatment of patients with BN and BED. It may be an alternative for certain patients who prefer it over CBT –Resistance training -Authors of an RCT(N = 36) found that a high-intensity resistance training program that was adapted for adolescents was effective and safe for patients with AN and resulted in increased muscular strength and agility. All participants in the study were patients in the psychiatry/psychology unit of a pediatric hospital at the time of the study(30) -High-intensity  resistance training group: Patients participated in 3 sessions per week for 8 weeks in the hospital gym and were given increased protein in their daily diet. Each intervention session was 50 to 60 minutes in length and consisted of a warm-up,  resistance training, and cool-down.  The resistance training involved three sets of 8–10 repetitions on weight-lifting machines; the load started at 70% of 6-repetition maximum (RM) and was gradually progressed 5% to 10% at a time as the patient’s strength increased -Control group: Patients had psychological therapy and the same medical treatment as the high-intensity  resistance training group except for the exercise portion and increased protein intake -At the conclusion of the study, patients in the high-intensity  resistance exercise group had significantly greater upper and lower body strength than those in the control group. Improvements were observed on the TUG 3-minute  and 10-minute  tests and the Timed Up and Down Stairs (TUDS); however, these were not statistically significant. The authors noted that during treatment the patients in the intervention group did not decrease in weight or BMI despite the exercise training

Group therapy(12,15,23) –Group therapy can center on IADLs such as cooking or shopping(12) –Sometimes provided in the form of family therapy in which the goal of therapy is to help the family reframe the view of thinness as an ideal and to solve any underlying family issues that contribute to the patient’s maladaptive behaviors(23) -The therapist facilitating family therapy is most often a psychologist or family counselor; however, the OT can be present and often offer helpful insight(23)

COPM as part of treatment –Authors of a study (N = 63) found that the use of a measure to assess perceived occupational performance in children and adolescents with eating disorders can produce favorable outcomes. Patients with eating disorders who participated in a specialized pediatric day-treatment  program improved their COPM scores. The authors concluded that helping patients self-identify  goals during treatment of their eating disorder may help to foster autonomy and improve treatment engagement(44)

Biofeedback(27) –Eating disorders can be associated with traumatic events and/or a history of sexual abuse; the patient can have physical reactions (increased heart rate, difficulty breathing) to triggers of these traumatic events and the eating disorder becomes their way to regain control(27) . stabilization of weight: For this population, one objective measure is the patient’s weight (usually as a weekly weigh-in)(2)
engagement in new roles or reengagement: Lawton and Brody Instrumental Activities of Daily Living Scale
Barthel Activities of Daily Living Index

maintenance or prevention: Efforts to prevent eating disorders The American Psychological Association (APA) recommends programs in healthcare settings, schools, and communities that integrate the prevention of eating disorders and disordered eating with obesity prevention efforts  –The necessary components for these programs include education on proper nutrition, an active lifestyle, a healthy body image, and “life skills” (e.g., effective stress management) as well as efforts to reduce teasing and stigmatization based on a person’s weight and shape

Findings from a study called “Project EAT” (Eating Among Teens) recommended five ways in which healthcare providers can help to prevent both eating disorders and obesity among teens(28) Discourage unhealthy dieting; promote positive eating and physical activity behaviors Do not use body dissatisfaction as a motivator for teenagers to make changes; focus on creating a healthy body image and positive self-talk Encourage families to engage in regular, enjoyable family meals Encourage families to reduce discussions about “weight” and instead focus on health Assume that overweight teenagers have been teased about their weight; discuss openly with teens and families
Prevention efforts should target adolescent females aged 15 and older, especially those with significant risk factors for developing an eating disorder(3)

General prevention Encouraging a rational attitude about both nutrition and weight(2) Reducing the focus on thinness as an ideal, especially by parents of teenagers(2,3,9,11) Minimizing weight-related  criticism/teasing(2) Managing overly high self-expectations(2) Improving self-esteem(2,3) Focusing on a healthy lifestyle rather than body image(2) Teaching stress-  or anxiety-management  skills(3,9) Managing symptoms of anxiety and/or depression(3)
Both eating breakfast and having family meals have been associated with prevention of eating disorders in adolescent girls(9)

After treatment for an eating disorder, patients will likely require follow-up  care to maintain a healthy weight and healthy attitudes about food and weight(2) Initially, the patient will require follow-up  with weekly weigh-ins; once patient is stable and forward progress is documented, the visits will decrease to once monthly(2) Help the patient to focus on enjoyable activities instead of goal-oriented  ones(2) Emphasize the importance of moderate activity and a nutritious diet for health, not for thinness(2) To prevent relapse in patients with BN, it is recommended that the patient remain on a full therapeutic dose of antidepressants for 1 year(3)
patient education: Provide patient and family member(s) with information about the diagnosis as well as its health risks and treatment strategies(2)

See the help and support page on the National Eating Disorders Association (NEDA) website, https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/help-support Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
